Pros: IBM’s gives plenty of training opportunities and encourages their workers to constantly upskill. If you have the right accounts, you can make a lot of money with minimal efforts.
Cons: If you have the wrong account mix or there is no ELA closing for your accounts, you can find it really difficult to make your numbers. Quota is based on assumptions that are often wrong. You will have multiple managers that are mainly interested in forecasting and will often push you towards how they want you to forecast in order to appease their superiors, regardless of whether you feel the numbers are accurate.

Pros: IBM stands as a titan in the tech industry, renowned not only for its diverse array of products such as the pioneering IBM Mainframe technology, which has served as the bedrock of enterprise computing for generations, alongside Red Hat, AI, IBM Cloud, and quantum computing innovations. Beyond its groundbreaking products, IBM Consulting Services emerges as a formidable force, ranking among the top five consulting firms in the USA. This holistic approach underscores IBM's commitment to providing comprehensive solutions that drive innovation and empower businesses to thrive in an ever-evolving digital landscape.
Cons: While IBM Consulting Services excels in areas such as Mainframe modernization, Red Hat, SAP, and Salesforce integration, its performance in VMware vCenter migration to the cloud falls short of expectations.

Pros: Many very bright people; great professional, respectful, progressive, and inclusive culture; many complex problems that offer a lot to learn from, many job and training options within company; excellent core values, more collective and longitudinally successful contributions to computing than any other tech company out there; professionalism is higher than many other companies; less fad-driven than other big tech companies with more high focus on execution and delivery and expertise.
Cons: Pay level is usually lower than silicon valley or other competitive companies; "top winners take-all" compensation strategy creates relatively low pay increases each year unless top performer in org; lacks employment clout that other FANG-like companies command, regardless of actual employee talent, company capabilities, and technical vitality ("legacy underdog" status); routine layoffs depending on your part of company; outdated employee assessment policies; upper and middle management often provide little technical expertise and are more bureaucratic in their roles; C-Suite leadership has a varied and cyclical history of execution and growth (stock price can skyrocket or drop precipitously) but huge compensation packages regardless of success.

Pros: IBM is changing the world with ground breaking technology and working to improve lives. They are leaders in many areas and encourage their employees to continously learn and grow. They have a rich history of diversity and inclusion and encourage innovation.
Cons: IBM no longer wants employees working remotely, CEO Arvind Krishna doesn't believe it improves the business. They tend to lay people off or do "resource actions" every quarter and we would literally fear for our jobs when the quarterly financials would come out. We had 2 years, 2021 and 2022 that they committed to no resource actions but instead redeployments to move employees into other areas of the company if possible but that ended quickly in 2023 and it is also hard to move internally to a new role as current employees aren't a priority unless you are an exec or more "valuable" resource. Most employees don't feel valued but as more of just an asset and a number. They have started projects to change that and change the perspective but gave up on them when they found other ways to save money.

Pros: Working at IBM can be a rewarding experience. It offers great opportunities for learning and career growth, along with flexible work options and a supportive, inclusive environment.
Cons: Despite being a tech powerhouse with a storied past, IBM's marketing falls short. They seem to assume everyone already knows what they do/offer, but that’s not the case. The company's broad range of services and products often leads to confusing messages, leaving many people unsure about what IBM actually offers today. This disconnect makes it hard for them to reach new customers and showcase their innovations effectively.

Pros: Enjoyed working with people I enjoy.

Pros: Direct teammates are incredibly friendly and make it a fun environment to work
Cons: This company will entrap you into their ways of working and tech stack, which is entirely IBM-based (and no other company uses). Your skills won't be as applicable once it's time to leave. I do a lot of self-study on my own time to keep up with the lack of career growth here.

Pros:
They have some of the best tech on the market.
The regular employees there were wonderful.
My initial management team was great.
What I was hired to do would have been very fun.
Built great relationships across multiple departments quickly.
Cons:
6 weeks in they hired new senior management.
Senior Management was difficult to work with at best.
They were very demanding and if you asked for help or feedback were more likely to be talked down to and degraded than helped. They decided they wanted to replace certain people. Instead of laying off people they hand-selected who they wanted to let go, put them on a nearly impossible project with little to no support, and then fired them if they didn't complete the project to satisfaction which was a constantly moving set of goal posts.

Pros: Pay, remote work, and working alongside good, genuine people.
Cons: Management was useless. When I offboarded, HR never contacted me, which is very odd especially for how big of a company IBM is...So, I had zero guidance or help. You were truly a number here and nothing more. Roles and territory seem to change every six months to a year. You will finally become familiar with a client or an account, and then JK, it's pulled from you, and now you have to learn from the beginning about something or someone else. This happened to me about 8, maybe even more times in my 4.5 years at IBM, which is wrong. How can a sales rep or anyone succeed that way?

Pros: - My managers treat me with the up most respect and stand by me ALWAYS. - My colleague's are always reliable and help to make life possible outside of work. - The culture here provides many opportunities for self growth and the freedom to do it at your own choice. No one is forcing you to learn the new stuff coming out but there's all sorts of learning tools to start that process if you want to get ahead.
Cons: IBM's only downfall is the yearly budget cuts they do with employee's. Anytime market share is down they cut off employee's or find ways to cut overhead ... which often results in great people losing their job. This is literally the ONLY thing I dislike about IBM and its unfortunately something that scares me all the time.

Pros: Good Brand Name. There are good people in IBM however IBM doesn't recognize them and most of the great people leave. The harder you work doesn't pay off unless you have an inside scoop with the "good old boy" network. Yes.... it still exists inside of IBM!!!
Cons: Too Many to mention. Don't waste your time only if you want to put IBM on your resume and then move on... don't stay like I did.... IBM is only as good as your immediate manager. The Good old boy network is real inside! Always has been and always will be! After 20 years of "selling" IBM careers.....I was notified on a 2 min conference call "If you're invited to this call you are impacted"...I did not even get a "thank you" for your 20 years of service. NO Thank YOU just goodbye and we will email you later. This is heartbreaking and insulting to a TA person who "sold" what a great company IBM is and "close" candidates to join IBM for 20 years. IBM is not a great company they don't care about you.

Pros: Some people that have never worked at IBM think IBM is a great company that pays well. If you have excellent people skills/emotional intelligence/ are an expert in corporate politics you might make it
Cons: A lot of cliques. Did I say a lot of cliques? Lots of freeloaders. Lots of people who have been there for decades pretending to do work. Other teams doing the same work as your team with different ways. Lots of favoritism. They layoff like their behind is on fire by the thousands and they lie all the time about their numbers. CEO lies like a professional actor. If you don’t go with the flow you are part of the reduction in force (RIF). Management doesn’t care about you. At first they pretend they like you but turn on you when you have a different opinion or idea to make things better. IBM has too many legacy systems that are outdated and too many processes that are a waste of time. IBM has lots of bullies and managers do nothing to prevent it even if reported. Lack of diversity and inclusion. Most executives and managers are white. There’s lack if respect. Don’t share anything personal. Lots of envy if you share any good news about your personal life.

Pros: It's a great place to learn about large scale backend systems. Pay ok. Some can get away with slacking off. But that is not me.
Cons: Pay is not competitive with other tech companies of the same scale. The CEO has taken away our 401k match which was a major pro. Pros: Plenty of training and access to a Udemy business account as well as the company paying for certifications.
Cons: Management constantly belittling employees causing damage to the mental health of those employees while the behavior is never addressed. Spent over 3 years with the company and they provided me and others with no actual projects, just had us changing training topics every week or two, gaining surface level knowledge without any practical experience. All practical experience I gained was doing projects on my own time after work hours because I was simply told "Learn X on Udemy" This made it incredibly difficult to speak to ones abilities when finding a new job on top of the dread of opening my laptop every day. On top of walking back their remote work policy and having me go back to spending 2+ hours a day in traffic that I could instead be spending with my family. It never felt like a team environment with everyone stuck on Udemy with their headphones on anyway. Got calls regularly on weekend evenings (8-9 pm)to design and develop features that weren't urgent just because one of the architects didn't have anything else to do and wanted us to work on these features right away and not charge the client for those hours worked. Compensation is about half of what it should be and getting a raise is like pulling teeth even if you meet all of the requirements.

Pros: In my 30 years at IBM I have only had one manager that wasn't 100% above average. Their managers have almost always been outstanding. The training for any and every position I have held with IBM has been outstanding. Everything has always been explained fully and all questions answered. The work environment has always been positive. Questions and new ideas are encouraged. Working from home (when your roll permits) has never been a problem. Building teams of incredible people is easy. The benefits package is good. Holidays, vacation time, sick time, medical
Cons: If you are not gunning for that next promotion, pay raises are not frequent. 1%-3% has been the rule, rather than the exception. If you are applying for a job, ask for a higher number in the pay range. Don't settle for the minimum in the pay range. There is a plethora or training that you can take in many fields. With the constant development of new technologies, new platforms, and new applications, along with acquisitions of smaller companies, the amount of required training can be overwhelming.

Pros: Work flexibility until recently with the RTO mandate.

Pros: Breadth of work - you really get exposed to tons of different areas and issues and the internal clients are varied. IBM is always cooking up something new, constantly evolving and the heavy emphasis on AI makes it an exciting place to work. They truly let you unplug when you go on vacation. People are truly out of office and there is no pressure to check in.
Cons: Vastly different levels of manager quality. Some are great and supportive, while others couldn’t care less about their reports. Get the sense managers aren’t required to take any training once they stay managing people, which leads to very different calibre managers. If you get stuck with a bad one, life can be tough. I’ve never had to put so much effort into managing my manager before. Has had an enormous effect on my feelings about my job.

Pros: A culture of generally thoughtful, ethical, open and driven colleagues, leaders and subject matter experts across the globe. I've witnessed, first hand, a history of putting our clients needs and our ethics ahead of all else. It's almost impossible to get stale in your career IBM if you are someone who seeks growth and has proven ability to deliver. In my experience, there have been challenges and opportunities around every corner and the work at a global scale is hard, REALY hard at times, but nothing compares to the gratification of achievement. I know I could do similar work at other large tech companies, but it's the people I get to do it with and the ethical foundation our work stands on, that keeps me engaged happy here.
Cons: You have to have patience and perseverance to navigate the waters and break through layers of process, protocols and compliance to get major work done . IBM is a finance led company. We will never be the cash cow . Employee compensation is fair/market but no one is trumpeting the horns on bonus amounts. As a leader - It can be brutal at times, trying influence finance to loosen our purse strings for the right investments. It can feel short sighted and sometimes it is. That said, I recognize, we are a tech company that has been in business for 100+ years. Clearly, a history of good business strategy but begrudgingly I also have to give due credit to financial management... no matter how frustrating it can be.

Pros: Company places great emphasis on employee learning, community involvement, and promoting recognition. Large company with a wealth of resources for all of the above, from business resource groups, webinars, trainings, town halls, etc. Day-to-day employee culture can be open and friendly. Good/fair compensation. A lot of employees with long-term tenure means the company has done a lot of great things. Lots of smart people. Some things move very efficiently. Lots of opportunities for training and advancement. Culture and performance obviously varies greatly by department. Flexible work culture. Responsible company.
Cons: Big company and a lot of employees (especially those with long tenure) tend to be averse to change or improvement. Sometimes all the focus learning, training, etc feels a bit superficial as it does not necessarily prompt a better work culture or environment. (For all the wonderful IBMers, I have unfortunately encountered too many IBMers -including senior managers-who lack collegiality, and exhibit unprofessional - even nasty- behavior and I wonder how they get away with it.) It can be to influence without a higher level title and senior management can feel inaccessible. HR is a generally a nightmare as everything (for the most part) is handled through bots or third parties. The benefits policies are just okay (at least in comparison to peers) and the healthcare benefits themselves are not so great.

Pros: Very easy work. Doing basic tasks can make you a top performer. People are happy with cushion jobs of not doing too much. Also good benefits.
Cons: There was never any effort from leadership to show me career growth path. On top of that I was very misled in terms of travel requirements for the project I was assigned to. Before starting they told me it would be 100% travel for 2 weeks, and then “we will see where it goes”. In reality the client expected us to travel indefinitely. I raised concerns about the amount of travel but was ignored. I explained that if the travel stayed the same then I would want to leave the project by the end of 2022, but was ignored and essentially forced to stay on the project going into 2023. After a year with the company, I scheduled time to meet with my leadership team (who by the way never scheduled time to meet with me. No 1 on 1s or anything) and I asked about a raise or promotion. I was immediately shut down and told nothing happens for at least two years. I know that’s a lie because my colleague received a promotion for reaching the 1 year benchmark. By the end of that meeting with the leaders, they were calling me the wrong name (Another individual on my team). It was clear to me they did not care about me at all, and at that point I began aggressively applying elsewhere.

If you are in the US, prepare for layoff anxiety every quarter. 401k match is gone as of 2024. Clear pattern of targeting older employees for layoffs.

Pros: IBM is recreating itself and doing some really cool things in the Quantum and AI space. IBM isn't flashy but it is dependable. The work-life balance is great. The pay scales are better at the tail end of the bands. You're not getting the hyper-inflated pay but you're also not being worked to the bone. IBM gets a bad rep because it's compared to a lot of other bloated companies. It's actually an amazing place to work.
Cons: IBM isn't going to have free Breakfast, Lunches, and Dinners. You're not going to get any handouts either. IBM works very well for a self-starter or someone that's willing to put in the extra mile to succeed. There aren't currently a lot of perks (events, happy hours, free merch). It's a little grindy at the moment if you want to progress upward. You also, and probably most importantly are at a company where they're rediscovering what it means to be profitable. There's a lot of belt-tightening going on.

Pros: The two biggest pros to me are the inclusive culture and strong connection with fellow IBMers and management, and the endless opportunities to grow and learn new skills. For culture, IBM truly lets you bring your authentic self to work. I feel completely comfortable in being who I identify with, and there are so many resources for employees to connect with other IBMers. I always feel that my colleagues, manager, and leadership team provide an open and welcoming environment for everyone, regardless of race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, or gender identity or expression. I just feel that I can be myself and ask questions and be open with others. I can't tell you how many deep conversations I've had with my direct managers about my personal and professional goals. They always listen, and I mean truly listen, to my thoughts and plans and always offer feedback, and sometimes just lend an ear if I need to talk to someone. And regarding growing my career and learning new skills, the opportunities at IBM are endless. We have frequent check-ins with our managers where we receive constructive feedback about our accomplishments and areas to improve. Open communication is always happening. We also have an internal learning platform where I can take online courses and watch videos on a variety of skills to help me improve my knowledge base and increase my skill set.
Cons: Working for IBM has been the best experience of my career. Every company has a few things that can improve, but nothing here that I would label a "con". I truly love my job, my manager, my colleagues, and the leadership in my division (Talent Acquisition) and look forward to working here for a long time.

Everything is pushing towards decreased productivity and market competitiveness - Senior leadership is not good and has been frequently violating our own business conduct guidelines in recent all-hands meetings

Management does not have the proper controls in place to manage offshore development and then wonders why deliverables do not turn out what they were expecting 4. Too much middle management. What is the purpose of these people and why are we paid $500K to a $1M dollars per year. Where is the transparency for what the are doing? 5. Management is solely focused on making the quarterly dividend which they keep raising every quarter and/or year. This leads to more of a short term focus on making everyone billable and less time for reusable asset making or working on bids and proposals. 6. Interview your management team wisely. Picking a the wrong managment team can be detrimental to your career.

Pros: Competitive salary and nice offices
Cons: I've been with IBM for over four years, and even the management during COVID was concise and clear. I used to love it. Now, for over six months, we're in some unofficial, ambiguous hiring freeze. There was some restructuring going on, and the budget for 2023 was supposed to be announced in February 2023. Then March 2023. It's April 2023 and there is STILL no budget for 2023. Meanwhile, IBM boasts 4,4% growth in revenue, and executives are sending out general e-mails demanding excellence. My team has been understaffed since Q4 2022, and there is ongoing employee turnover - things are expected to worsen. Grandious failure of executives to communicate anything about the budget and plans for 2023. I am unbelievably disappointed in IBM and its management. They pretend that all is well, have the ignorance to demand maximum performance from their employees, but ignore our daily reality. I will not work a minute overtime to compensate for their inability to manage until some form of official communication addresses my concerns. I do not recommend joining IBM at this point in time.

Pros: IBM is a great place to develop. The company plays across the entire tech industry, has a huge consulting arm, and does cutting edge research. It's a steady ship and doesn't tend to get rocked by larger macro events, so it has good job security. The people are great, and it's a very collaborative environment. There are opportunities to switch positions fairly regularly, and as such you can grow your career at IBM. Oh, and the work-life balance is pretty darn great.
Cons: The compensation and benefits are not in line with the rest of the tech industry. Promotions are relatively slow, but at regular intervals. Over and above performance is not rewarded below the executive level. So, if you bust your butt more than your coworker, you'll likely still get promoted at the same time. You probably won't feel as challenged here as you would at a startup or faster growing company.

Pros: Benefits, support staff, colleagues were great
Cons: Resource Actions, poorly articulated corporate and divisional strategy

Pros: You get to sell cutting edge products with some of the smartest people around.
Cons: Google "IBM Age Discrimination Lawsuit" and brace yourself. The Google "IBM Commissions lawsuits" for round two. In 30 years in sales, I have never had a company try to screw me out of a very large commission the week after a deal signed. They claimed there had been an administrative error and cancelled my incentive letter, issuing a new one for me to sign that would have cut my commission in half. There was no mistake. I knew the compensation plan my colleagues were on and it was the same as mine. Managers who I thought were friends were spineless and went along with this farce. When I sought legal representation, I was surprised to learn how common this practice was. IBM has a culture that promotes technocrats, not leaders. You can make good money at IBM, if they decide to pay you. Current sales management cannot be trusted.

Pros: Work in a large-scale organization with numerous opportunities to learn from teams worldwide. Close collaboration between engineering, research and product teams. Senior managers have good moral standards and provide support for career development of subordinates.
Cons: Sometimes you have to work with people from very diverse backgrounds, resulting in a lack of efficiency in communication and accomplishing tasks

Pros: Almost everyone I have worked with in consulting and sales has been pleasant to work with. There are some less friendly people of course, but most everyone generally wants to help each other out and support where they can. Work-life balance is also superb, manageable levels of stress.
Cons: Strategy and guidance from management can be conflicting, change often, and be unrealistic.

Pros: Great people, opportunity available for those willing to do the work.
Cons: DEI and continued wokeness at leadership levels is changing the company for the worse.

Pros: IBM is so focused on learning. They offer hundreds of thousands of free courses on Udemy and O'Reilly. Managers will also get you setup with courses with live instructors teaching. Everyone at the office I work at is set on finding a project for you. Until you find one, just soak all the knowledge that you can, it's offered to you and encouraged. While you are "on the bench" (not on a project) and most projects, everyone is extremely flexible. Everyone has a life outside of work and mostly everyone knows that. I think this is a fantastic environment and place to work. I'm proud to be an IBMer.
Cons: I can't really think of one. However, I do want to talk about 1 con that I have seen a lot. IBM does require on some projects that you work 45 hours week. There is a reason for this. Remember all of that free education you received, that certification you didn't pay for that will follow you anywhere you go, the paychecks you received during this, when all you have done at this point is cost the company money? This is where you make up for it. Now that you are generating income for IBM, that extra hour a day is your repayment. 1000% Worth it if you ask me. I would have spent thousands of dollars on the courses, live classes, and certifications I have received, if it wasn't for IBM investing in me.

Pros: amazing co-workers, extremely talented people and generous family planning support (20 weeks of paid parental leave and non-birthing parents have 12 weeks)
Cons: Other than being very attracted to IBM's parental leave policy which I could benefit from in the near future, I am considering running so far from IBM. Leadership has dangled a promotion in front of me for 9+ months and everyone who was expecting a promotion October 15th was told at 5pm on Friday evening they are all pushed to January 1st. I have 90%+ utilization and brining in $$ guaranteed revenue stream for the next year on a client engagement. My overall team is ~20% female of which there is zero (0%) female representation at the leadership (exec) level. This company no longer aligns to my values.

Cons: Lots of incompetent managers. Management does no real work. They just cook up bad ideas about things they know nothing about. Then makes their team implement their bad ideas. Management is getting rid a lot of US workers and moving these jobs to other countries like India and Mexico to save a buck, while holding on to their own jobs. They threatened their employees to get a vaccine or stop working. They made a vaccine policy based on Joe Biden's unconstitutional mandate. They likely did this due to further reduce employees numbers in the US. IBM lost employees without finding replacements for them. The work gets passed to current employees, and IBM refused to compensate employees for taking on additional work duties. IBM made employees take Diversity & Inclusion training similar to Coca-Cola's training that educated employees "To Be Less White" I seen IBM's first hand practices of hiring large amounts of young employees. They called it Vitality Hiring. After the new younger employees got their training from older, more seasoned workers, IBM would have massive amounts of layoffs. Of course, the older higher paid employees get laid off, while the new young employees were safe from the layoff. IBM is a disgraceful company, don't be fooled by their fake reputation of being a honorable company. They are far from it.

Pros: As an Associate Consultant, I have jumped right into building my career, all while focusing on serving the client and growing the IBM Consulting practice. IBM is a place for young professionals who are will to say yes to the call, seek to serve the needs of others, and individuals who have a growth mindset. Each day as a Consultant can look a little different, whether it is printing documents for the client or even presenting in front of key industry leaders, IBM will give you the platform to harness skills that will develop your leadership capabilities and enhance your business acumen, all while allowing you to voice your personal career goals.
Cons: At IBM, we seek to build client trust above all else. While that can be a highly rewarding and build a lot of your professional growth, it also limits the bandwidth I have to dedicate to internal IBM initiatives. Balancing client work alongside IBM work is something many Consultants find hard to discern, however, there are so many leaders with more experience willing to help give actionable advice to combat the challenge.

Pros: Remote job, decent pay, decent benefits
Cons: At IBM, you’re just a cog in a giant wheel in an ever more monstrous machine. During the Covid pandemic, IBM implemented a vaccine requirement for ALL employees regardless of work model. I was a remote employee who never set foot in an IBM office ever, and I have a valid medical exemption. I submitted my medical exemption to comply with their new policy, and they rejected it saying they needed more “proof”. So my doctor of over 15 years wrote out a lengthy explanation of why I’m unable to receive any vaccines & provided his contact info so they could investigate further if they would like, but they still rejected it & put me on notice that I would be terminated if I did not provide proof of Covid vaccine. I tried to talk to someone in HR to try to get an actual human to look at this situation objectively & do the right thing, but I was literally refused any actual human contact with HR. I was only able to email the generic HR inbox & id get a reply from a different person every time. Couldn’t even reply directly to the HR rep that would message back. Could only “reply” to the generic HR email. How is a corporate company who has never had any actual human contact with me allowed to override the medical expertise of a doctor who has treated me for fifteen years?! SHAMEFUL!!

Pros: Access to F100 C-Suite, Access to Resources
Cons: IBM has now been downsizing for well over a decade by laying off employees and spinning off whole business units. As a retired long-term IBM employee, it was sad to see the company go into freefall. There was huge pressure to generate revenue by cutting corners and using "bait and switch" with customers. IBM had gone through a period were they just laid off all of their older, experienced workers and had completely fumbled the transition to cloud. In my region IBM had had multiple projects cancelled due to poor performance due to understaffing. IBM responded by laying off more people and putting more pressure on the remaining staff to sell more, at any cost. IBM is now in a situation where they are an afterthought when compared to Google, Microsoft and Amazon.

They also just switched their 401k matching program to put what they match into an RBA, rather than into your own 401k like that use to. That's a big no for me.

IBM also helped me transition from working on the road fulltime to working remotely affording me the ability to have and raise my family while being home.
Cons: For all the talk of diversity, when it came down to layoffs the men banded together to make the decisions and often the women were let go. Additionally, there is currently a strong focus to move jobs overseas and reduce workforce in the USA.

Pros: IBM knows that you grow in your life as you grow in your career and makes space for that. If you can do the bare minimum at a certain time it’s not the end of the world, if you can go over the top your work will be appreciated with bonuses, raises, and opportunities in my experience. It’s a good place to grow.
Cons: They enterprise for other enterprises. So things move slowly compared to other tech companies. And they are slower to adopt new concepts and methodologies than other tech companies. In my experience everywhere they say they do agile development is truly waterfall masked as agile. But I don’t have much to compare to so maybe that’s normal.

When the CEO is cornered with questions on RTO policies his responses often start with "in my day when I was a manager 30 years ago..."

That day of his is [almost] before the internet...

If you work here you’ll get more work and less people to do it, because everyone wants to leave and when they do ibm won’t hire to replace them. Ibms current mantra is do stuff faster, but they won’t pay or hire to do that, they’ll just expect you to work more. And cut your benefits so you’re cheap or quit. This is not a long-term company.

Pros:
- TONS of free training
- Project-based work keeps things fresh with each project feeling like a new job
- Projects give you a lot of experience very quickly
- Very flexible with outside circumstances, office vibe is very “as long as the work gets done, we can work with you”
- Coworkers are very friendly and welcoming
- Plenty of in-office events and free food almost every week
- Great health insurance
- Lots of miscellaneous benefits like adoption expense assistance, paternity leave, and employer contributions for health premiums on family plans after 2 years of employment, highly recommend reading through all of the benefits in the benefit summary
Cons:
- Not all benefits are available to consultants 
- If your skills aren’t in-demand, it can be hard to find a project
- Bench time feels very stressful since you’re worried about being let go if you can’t find a project
- Workload and job satisfaction can vary drastically from project to project. Some projects are too easy or have too little work, and some projects will have you working 12 hour days. Some projects have no travel, and others can have an excessive amount of travel.
- Pay is less than competitors in tech, but still higher than most non-tech employers (in my area). Great place to start for the training and varied projects, but you may need to leave to get the high salaries you’ve heard about in tech.

Pros: A good salary is the only positive thing I can say. I only thank this company for the opportunity to make a decent salary. It helped me a lot.
Cons:
Reflecting on my tenure at IBM in 2023 compels me to share the profound challenges that markedly influenced my professional journey. My aim is not to disparage but to candidly outline my experiences, hoping that it might spur constructive dialogue and foster a more favorable environment for future employees.

The work culture I encountered was, regrettably, far from what I had envisioned for a company of IBM's repute. It was a culture that seemed to undervalue diversity and inclusivity, not merely in terms of initiatives but in the fundamental respect for the varied perspectives that each team member brings. This disregard for diversity was a precursor to a broader issue—a palpable lack of collaboration, where projects often succumbed to personal egos rather than converging towards mutual success.

Compounding these issues was the absence of support and mentorship from my direct supervisor. Guidance, encouragement, and constructive feedback are pivotal for any professional's growth, yet these were conspicuously missing. The absence of direction not only hampered my development but also left me feeling isolated within a team, struggling to navigate through the professional challenges without a mentor.

The general lack of support extended across the organization, with human resources seemingly indifferent to the employees' grievances. This lack of engagement from HR further solidified the sense of neglect, making it incredibly challenging to see a pathway for growth or resolution of issues within the company.

Management and HR's inaction towards fostering a supportive and collaborative environment made my experience at IBM in 2023 the most disheartening chapter of my career in the United States. It was a culture steeped in self-interest, overshadowing the collective well-being and the innovative spirit that IBM has historically been known for.

Sharing this experience is not about dwelling on the past but about emphasizing the critical need for a supportive work environment. It underscores the importance of mentorship, respect for diversity, and collaborative spirit—essential for personal growth and organizational success. I hope bringing these issues to light encourages IBM and similar organizations to re-evaluate their culture, ensuring a more inclusive, supportive, and growth-oriented environment for all employees.

Pros: The organization skillfully crafts an enchanting facade through charismatic and charming individuals who deliver captivating speeches, fostering a warm and inviting atmosphere—an aspect that is truly valued. This practice not only contributes to client satisfaction and fleeting moments of joy but can occasionally lead to an excess of humor within the company, creating a slightly peculiar atmosphere. However, it is apparent that this is an effort to convey friendliness and openness.
Cons:
as one delves deeper, it becomes apparent that the higher echelons of management lack experience beyond the company. Their trajectory has been confined within the organization, resulting in promotions to high executive positions without acquiring the market-level skill sets essential for the company's size and type.

Challenges in Career Advancement:

In the initial stages, when the company was smaller, promotions occurred at a rapid pace—four times a year—with minimal criteria. However, with the company's expansion, the influx of experienced professionals working under the old employees, many of whom received higher titles than their skills warranted, has shifted the promotion landscape, making advancements more challenging. with opaque promotion criteria. Individuals in client-facing roles, where client feedback plays a pivotal role in promotions, are typically occupied by long-term employees and mostly who hold high titles, giving them a distinct advantage. This creates a disparity, with dedicated engineers contributing significantly to the actual work, facing challenges in securing promotions. Furthermore, the feedback loop from leaders crucial for promotions seems biased, as leaders are often reluctant to acknowledge those who may outshine them. The emphasis on client feedback, which holds way more value than the leader's evaluation, adds an additional layer of complexity.

Issues in Project Execution:

In the realm of project execution, the initial phase involves selecting the right people for leadership roles for each project. However, if the top leadership lacks the necessary technical skills, they struggle to identify and hire the right leaders for the project. Often, leaders are chosen based on familiarity, connections, or charm, resulting in projects led by individuals with less expertise than their team members. This situation leads to delivering subpar products, attributed to poorly structured projects and demotivated engineers aware that only leaders receive promotions.

Now, I routinely assess an individual's entry date into the company to discern their genuine skill level when interacting with them. However, I've heard that in the past, the company had exceptionally skilled engineers who have since departed—there might still be a few that I have not encountered yet (old team).

Dubious Policies:

The company is inundated with policies, with new ones emerging regularly alongside numerous committees. While having clear policies is beneficial, there is a concern that some are misleading or subject to frequent changes. For instance, the evolution of policies such as "Responsible PTO" raises concerns about inconsistency and limitations on employee benefits. The introduction of new policies without clear communication adds to the confusion. Policies that once offered unlimited PTO have transformed into enforced maximums with potential rejections and unpaid leaves.

Employee Challenges:

Noteworthy among the policies is one that heightens job insecurity: termination in two months if the company fails to secure a project for an employee. This creates anxiety among employees, pressuring them to accept engagements regardless of personal preferences or suitability. The consequence is an exodus of experts and experienced professionals seeking stability elsewhere, leaving behind those who couldn't find alternative employment.

In conclusion, there is a disparity between the company's external charm and its internal challenges. Addressing issues related to leadership skills, promotion criteria, and policy consistency is crucial for the organization's long-term health and sustained success. The company's practice of conducting surveys and seeking feedback should be complemented by a genuine commitment to addressing the identified issues.

Pros: 1. The people are intelligent, kind, and passionate about what they do at IBM Consulting. Innovative leaders are empowering and inspiring! 2. Benefits are wonderful! WFH, 401K w/ 6% match, 3 weeks vacation + 4 personal holidays + 7 days sick time, marriage leave (1 week), maternal/ paternal leave (3 months), miscarriage leave (up to 4 weeks in per year), and many other EAP benefits. IBM is ahead of the game. 3. Diversity and Inclusion are central to the organization, you can find a place at IBM where your culture/ identity is supported and uplifted. ERGs actually host engaging events. 4. Mentorship opportunities are what you make of it! (pro & can be a con) 5. Grow your curiosity with endless training opportunities and certifications!
Cons: Big company, if you are not actively building your network and making a deliberate effort to connect with others virtually it is easy to get overlooked. Some leaders you encounter still have old school mentality... you are not a good consultant unless you are putting in 70+ hours building decks/ relationships/ pulling together research. We have lives, families, and hobbies outside of work and it is okay to have busy weeks but busy months and busy years are not sustainable. If you encounter one, be patient, work hard, and move onto the next project. Not all leaders work like this, find another that fits your way of working.

Pros: You get a paycheck, this week.
Cons: This CNN headline on 1/31/24 is exactly why I left years ago as these so-called leaders were doing the same thing; cutting staff under the thin veil of what they called "co-location". It is nothing more than that. My advice? Leave! Your quality of life and career will improve, drastically. Just ask anyone that took the leap they'll all tell you the very same thing. There are still entire teams that even when on site, work at great distances from each other across vastly different time zones; they are not working together even when in an office - it's a ruse. Those of us that built what used to be idolized as the great IBM of old, is long gone. We built IBM's reputation - not the recent leadership (if you can even confer that on them). Also long gone and buried with Old Man Watson (9-edge, face down as they say) is the company's original mantra - "Respect for the Individual" and "Think" there is no respect anymore - and these greedy executives don't and can't think; employment is purely transactional and employees became faceless widgets long ago. Current employees are paid just enough but have been loaded with FUD - too scared to leave and ridden by first-line managers that only carry out orders from above after getting their spine-ectomies. Those with skills and value can do far better elsewhere and avoid getting stomach ulcers from living under constant anxiety. The new generation and top talent demand remote work options. My advice to you is this: take a clue - exclude Big Blue from your short list of best places to work, unless you want to work under constant FUD. Don't walk away - run!

Pros: Work with and build cutting edge technologies. Strong career development opportunities. Salaries are good.
Cons: Massive bureaucratic overheads impede quick actions and productivity. Technical architects frequently change direction to 'the next big' thing forcing massive rework by application teams. This is good if all you care about is technology but prevents application teams delivering business value and can turn a growing business offering into one that is stalled. When layoffs occur, those selected are rarely chosen based on poor performance. Instead it's typical for a entire location to be shutdown and then the work offshored to a cheaper geo. If you're at IBM then get those excellent skills and experience but then use them to get a better job somewhere else before they screw you over. Because they will screw you over eventually.

Pros: CEO has been and is refocusing the majority of the product line to deliver on Public, Private, and Hybrid Clouds for Customers. Great hardware that scales far better than competition. Has always and will continue to support Hybrid work environment (office/remote/home) Great place for Women in Technology to work!
Cons: Senior HR leadership is a problem. Multiple ridiculous internal programs and changes per year that are poorly communicated and frequently launched to fix things that are not broken. 100% of these HR programs impact the company and it's morale and are frequently kicked off without complete business alignment. Every SVP has a "program" to do "something" to change the business - some of these programs are massive work with little tangible gain, others are cost cutting. Employee pay is frequently sub-par compared to similar roles in competing companies. Executive pay is far too high. (read the public reports for numbers) There is an ongoing insane "diversity drum" beat. It pounds constantly in a company that's already quite diverse and is now openly targeting against India males and white males. There are multiple high level roles that do nothing of value for IBM customers or the company and are purely tied to "woke" programs.

The emphasis is on sales, sales, sales, and not delivery. Benefits are horrible for such a large company. Health insurance is extremely expensive and has high deductibles. Working at IBM feels like it's 1980-1985 all over again, there are thousands of homegrown archaic systems that do not interface and the majority of back-office work and data analysis is performed manually via Excel, rendering the IBM tools/systems completely useless aside from leveraging them as a DW/system of record. For a company that loves to give off "innovative" vibes to the public by spending huge amounts of $$ on advertising/ commercials etc, they dont even know what innovation is - its a huge front. AskHR has improved slightly over the past few years but their AI capability has a very long way to go.

Pros: I'm sorry, but really none at all
Cons:
I was hired for my second job after working with Python at a previous company. I had just completed the Austin Community College courses in Python and Java.

As soon as I was hired, I was sat at a desk and told to manually test a website. I asked for github access and was denied, even read-access. I asked the PMs to include me in scrums and assign me tickets, the PM never talked to me. Every time I would go to his desk, he would say he was busy, every single time. I had no idea what features the devs were working on. When I tried to ask devs directly, my boss would say I was 'bothering' them. I was told not to talk to the devs ever. I was told I was hired for my 'customer service' abilities and shouldn't expect to code. My boss hadn't added me to any jira boards or introduced me to a single person in development. I brought up to my boss how I was expecting an engineering org to work with QA- that I would be involved in scrum ceremonies where work was ticketed, assigned to a developer, and then tasks assigned to QA for either manual or automation. I was told by my boss to instead just keep testing the same UI over and over "like driving a car up and down the road, then left and right, then diagnonal". I was baffled. I also mentioned that I was hired as an automation engineer and my boss told me "not to worry about that".

A few months in, the company announced that they were switching to a python test automation project, which is something I had recent experience in. When I asked to work on that, I was told I didn't have a Computer Science degree and didn't have engineering experience, so I was denied.

I tried to bypass management at this point and talk to the engineers on that time. At one point I told someone I was sleeping 4 hours a day because I was required to be in both the 5:15AM standup and the 11:15PM standup by my boss. This standup included a bunch of people in India that I had no idea what relation they had to me and seemed to be working on a different project. I just knew I was mandated to be on the call. I was also taking 9 hours of college credit to prove I was "good enough" to code, even though I did have an MIS degree and several years of experience when they hired me. IBM was clear that they only counted Computer Science degrees so I was taking classes that would qualify me for that degree. The person I was talking to about my sleep issues told me 4 hours of sleep is too many, I should only sleep 2 hours a day. I should also mention that IBM's campus was pretty far from where I lived and having to attend both a late night and early morning standup was wearing on me so much that I rented out my condo at a loss of $100 a month to a friend and then got a studio apartment near IBM for the year. During this time period, I had to switch my internet but needed to secure the apartment before AT&T would switch my line over. Once I got the keys to the apartment, I requested to move my internet and was told it would take about 10 business days. My boss told me I needed to get internet 9 days earlier or I'd be fired, even though I'd already escalated the request and was given the earliest date. Keep in mind, I was ONLY moving because of IBM's standups. Not having internet for 9 days would be added to my PIP.

Six months in, I was also told there was a issue in the code bubbling up from customer service. When two people pressed a button in the UI at the same time, there was an API error. I was told that I was directly responsible for fixing this issue. I asked how I could be responsible for a race condition when not only was I not the developer, but I wasn't even given github access and able to see the repo that was causing the issue. I was put on a PIP.

I quit this job the morning and hour I was hired a year later. I was unable to quit earlier because I took a signing bonus that I couldn't afford to pay back before then. I was in a lot of medical debt when I took the job. 

The nature of the work also made it very hard to get another job. I had no idea how to present what I was doing in interviews. Eventually to interview better, I started a github project using my own name and started automating the public facing website. This project never integrated with IBM as a company and was never was looked at by a single person except me, but it was the only experience I was able to get at this job doing the thing they supposedly hired me for.

Also, the benefits are awful. Due to a chronic illness, i usually max out my insurance. IBM's max was 15k so I incurred 15k in medical expenses the year I worked for IBM on top of my previous medical debt.

Pros: If you are good at sales and/or self-promotion, you might be able to make it at IBM.
Cons:
I came on board as part of an acquisition. After an initial period of "this is going to be great!", it quickly became obvious that IBM had no clue what to do with our people or customers. One by one customers left and people were put on the bench. 

1. At IBM, you are basically on your own for finding work. Perhaps if you come into IBM and work your way up, you can build a network, but coming in through an acquisition, you are basically ignored. 

2. Folks at IBM are constantly begging (and yes, that's an appropriate term) for work, since there's little effort made to make sure people are staffed on projects. Even new hires often go onto the internal Slack groups begging for work before they're put on a PIP and shown the door.

3. There is no recognition of technical skills that I could see--it appeared the only way to get ahead was to get co-workers to write glowing reviews about you. If you worked for an external customer, you were expected to solicit reviews of your work. There is no way to simply do excellent technical work and be recognized without shameless self-promotion.

4. IBM prefers to staff technical resources from cheap overseas labor, so if you're like we were (well-compensated and based in North America), you're out of luck--you're too expensive for anybody to touch you.

5. HR is understaffed, to the point that when I resigned, my resignation got "lost" and I continued to get paid. Now I have to go through a mess to return money. It says something about a company when they have an entire elaborate website just for correcting overpayments to employees--there are obviously a lot of mistakes made.

Pros: - The work-life balance is decent and the workplace culture is modern. - Pay is fair for the work being done. - For the most part, coworkers are helpful and approachable, but as with everywhere, YMMV. - Opportunities for growth, although they need to be sought out. Employees are encouraged to take on side projects and contribute back to IBM (and beyond) so long as their primary obligations aren't impacted. - Decent career potential if staying at a company for over 5 years.
Cons: - HR is practically non-existent. - A high turn-around in more junior positions leads to unqualified individuals attaining high ranks simply because they stuck around. Experts on issues are few and far between. - The organization is so large that duplicate work gets done frequently, primarily due to poor collaboration between departments. - Teams aren't given any technical direction, so in most cases, tech stacks will vary significantly from team to team.

Pros: -remote ability (for me and some, not all) -if you find the right person to support you, you can go far (it's not easy) -health benefits (still good but have gone down over the last 10 years)
Cons: The longer I've been with IBM, the worse it's gotten. I've stayed for my ability to be remote but now that the industry has changed I plan on leaving and wanted to give an honest current review. -you are alone, the culture isn't there and you're better off going somewhere where you have control over your career if you're going to be doing it alone or that has any company culture -we don't have true HR (just a bot and system where you get a response in a few days from someone in HR via email & they close the ticket without seeing if it addressed the question/situation or actually making it a human experience) -people are afraid for their jobs and will keep people from advancing in their career or growing to protect them. Also for a lot of roles, you cannot advance until someone decides to take a new role or go somewhere else -promotion & compensation - you have to fight for everything and where can easily get a pay increase by going somewhere else -expectation of hours with out compensation (I understand other consulting companies have long hours as well, but do have solid structures in place to support and compensate based on work - we barely do bonuses, our review process is outdated & lengthy) -confusion around career path

Pros: Global Presence and Impact: IBM is a multinational technology company with a vast global presence. Working for IBM can provide you with opportunities to work on projects that have a significant impact on various industries worldwide. Cutting-Edge Technology: IBM has a long history of innovation and research in technology. As a software engineer, you might have the chance to work with cutting-edge technologies, participate in research, and contribute to the development of advanced solutions. Career Growth and Learning: IBM offers various training and development programs for its employees. You'll likely have access to resources for continuous learning, skill enhancement, and opportunities to grow within the company. Diverse Projects and Roles: IBM operates across a wide range of industries, from cloud computing and artificial intelligence to data analytics and cybersecurity. This diversity can provide software engineers with the chance to work on different types of projects and explore various roles. Work-Life Balance: IBM, like many established tech companies, often places emphasis on maintaining a healthy work-life balance. The company might offer flexible working arrangements and support initiatives that prioritize employee well-being.
Cons: Bureaucracy and Size: Due to its size and complexity, IBM can sometimes be perceived as having layers of bureaucracy. Decision-making processes might be slower and more convoluted in a large organization. Job Security: Like many corporations, IBM has undergone periods of restructuring and layoffs. Job security can be a concern, especially during challenging economic times or shifts in the company's strategic direction. Innovation Pace: While IBM is known for its history of innovation, some critics argue that the company has faced challenges in keeping up with the fast-paced changes in the tech industry compared to newer, more agile startups. Hierarchy and Advancement: Advancement within a large organization like IBM might require navigating a hierarchical structure. Progression might not always be solely based on merit, and some employees might find it challenging to move up the corporate ladder. Workload and Pressure: Depending on the specific role and project, software engineers at IBM might face high workloads and tight deadlines. Balancing the demands of the job with personal life can be challenging at times

Pros: Ethical. Focused on diversity and inclusion. Smart people. Good ability to move around and try new areas of the business with networking and a bit of hustle.
Cons: IBM prides itself on its scale. It achieves scale through silos that encourage teams to concentrate solely on their own metrics rather than achieving broader organizational goals. So while everyone likes to say "We're one IBM", the financial measurements do not encourage bigger picture thinking/action. The Software organization is in a state of disruption with customers moving away from single vendor purchasing to buying individual products from various vendors. Buying decisions are being pushed down from the CIO (where IBM has great relationships) to the folks actually using the products. IBM struggles with that because it has ignored user experience for so long, despite its touting of its Design organization.

Pros: - Work Life Balance After 6 months with IBM Consulting here are my key takeaways: - Great Pay & Benefits - Extremely organized - Resources and trainings available for nearly every interest you may have - Strong focus on employee development - Strong leadership team that empowers their team members - I feel my work makes an impact and my contributions are recognized by both my leadership and team members - You're surrounded by highly motivated and talented people which makes it easy to keep striving to improve - Strong collaborative culture
Cons: A few things to be aware of depending on your workstyle: - All employees start with only 15 vacation days plus 4 floating holidays and its either 5 or 10 years before you can gain more - Job titles can be difficult to track - It is a very large company which may not be for everyone - It is a fast paced and dynamic work environment so to really excel you'll need to be comfortable with change

Pros: I don't have many pros. I would at least say, based on my negative review, don't come to IBM until the current senior management leaves and there are actual good leaders who care. Or maybe do come and fight the good fight here with those of us trying to change the company by being vocal. Any rebels out there come join this century old company and shake things up. It sure needs it. :-)
Cons: IBM is forcing their employees to return to the office while also lying about having actual data to back up their reasons for this decision. IBMers have made it very clear to upper management they want their flexibility to chose how they work, not to be told how to work. The numbers IBM does have, but is denying they exist, is how during the pandemic when everyone was working remotely we produced the most amount of revenue the company has seen in years. Interesting IBM is choosing to omit that. I am not saying for the folks out there that like coming into the office that they should be remote too. No, I am saying IBMers want the freedom of choice to decide which works best for them. Not "mandating" us to do exactly what upper management wants. It really is despicable. What is worse, if this company would get its act together, the people who are not in upper management are lovely people and the best co-workers (I guess I do have a pro there). But I will say the few (CEO, Senior Leadership, all of that group) are ruining it for the many.

Pros: - They have some (if you are lucky enough) projects they are really interesting. - There are offices everywhere. - The 401k (in the US) package is not bad. - There are good people working there, not everything is bad at all.
Cons: I will start summarizing that IBM has been by far the worst company I have worked for in my career. I have worked in different companies in different countries and I wanted to try IBM because, you know, "it's an amazing technology company" that have created a lot of different patents. But once you started there you will notice that everything is still working old school. Then is when you notice IBM is not what it was in the past. These are the main point of views that are headaches: - Nothing is centralized, teams around IBM use different tools and processes, is like an anarchy. - Management is not transparent at all (I had the luck to have a manager who was really good, but the others I have... lies and smoke). - If you are in the Research department, probably this doesn't apply, but there are a lof of people hired who doesn't know anything about Agile methodologies, pipelines, DevOps... I have been working with teams that everything was manual. They didn't have anything automated, no version control, no documentation for people once they start in the team, just people "developing" without asking themselves "why I am doing this" or "what can I improve". They don't care about quality or documentation, and this was not a new team. - The CEO use to have some monthly sessions where he explains and answer questions that people ask. Don't let them lay to you, most of the things are lies. The most funny is he answered questions like "There will be layoffs in IBM?", he said "we are not going to do layoffs in the following months". Well, more than 19.000 were laid off two weeks after. - They bury you in paper and bureaucracy. Once you leave the company expect to receive 100 mails with papers. I recommend to hire a lawyer, because these guys retire the money from your 401k when they shouldn't, and when you reclaim they said you were right, but you have to notice it. Whatever, there are a lot of things that can be improved in IBM. I feel sad that a company like this, that was amazing before, now is like this. Recommendation: if you have other offers, take a look to the Glassdoor reviews (of course), but try to avoid this company. If you plan to retire here, I guess is a good company to do it, but if you plan to learn more and grow, forget about it.

And there are few places where you can work in any number of industries, anywhere on the global in any number of functional roles. It is a great career development experience.
Cons: Risk taking and enabling people to "fail fast" while trying new ideas in uncharted waters would allow some new innovative thinking. Plus there are many employees whose goal seems to be perseverance or self preservation instead of all in on company success. With over 400K employees it is to be expected but should not be tolerated.

Pros: Some days you can't get any work done because you're too busy helping others or supporting customers, and that is not punished. Insurance is decent if you spend the extra for the PPO plan. And don't add anyone but yourself to the plan. Never had a problem with remote working. While people near the office were forced back in against their will I was lucky enough to not be anywhere near any offices, so luckily was exempt from this farce of a policy. Understanding of personal and family issues that can arise unexpectedly, and PTO given for everyone often enough to feel like an actual reward. Lots of really good people to work with, as long as they aren't in management.
Cons: Oh boy. Pay is abysmal. My new job literally doubled my salary for the exact same job with much less responsibility and much better work/life balance. Management is inept at best, and maliciously incompetent at worst. Skeleton crews are common. Any project that requires 6-8 people to maintain normally will have three people at best, or just one (such as my case). A fetish for having contractors build things and FTEs maintain it afterward, which is literally the worst way to build software, especially when deadlines mean code reviews get tossed in order to deliver on time. Realistic deadlines get scoffed at. Sure Bob, one person can perform major version changes to several systems in a single two week sprint, while also doing support duty and 24/7 on-call for multiple teams around the world. All my coworkers felt "captive", and constantly looking for a better job. Sure doesn't help to build teamwork. Upper management is literally leeches patting themselves on the back and giving each other bonuses, even when their department utterly fails at every task. As long as they reduce headcount, they've won. Actual goals are irrelevant. Behind the curve on literally everything technology wise. Do not expect innovation to be rewarded. Sets the standard for "failing upward". Promotions are reserved specifically for those who are too incompetent to do their current job, so they can rain incompetence down upon their peers from above. Catering to anti-vaccine idiots. There was a small but loud uproar over vaccine policy, and IBM literally enabled that small but loud group to drown out all discourse with conspiracy theories and easily debunked lies. Luckily the most malicious of them were let go after they got too abusive over work chat, but all of those conspiracy theories should've been shot down as soon as they were reported.

Pros: Generally good work-life balance, job stability, and training.
Cons: My role is based out of a Client Innovation Center (CIC) and you should avoid at all costs if you want career progression. A CIC is an onshore cost center, so they expect you to work same projects as the core consulting practices, but they want to pay you half the salary. You'll be compensated peanuts compared to others doing the exact same job. The only instance that I would recommend the CIC is if you're absolutely desperate for a decent job. Just remember that you'll start off with an unfair salary, you won't get meaningful raises, and promotions are pretty much out of the question despite high performance. Overall, definitely do not overstay at a CIC. In this situation, you should only work for a year to get the experience and move on to another company that will actually value you.

Pros: Working for IBM has numerous advantages and benefits that can make it a highly fulfilling and rewarding career choice. As someone who has been with the company for 12 years, you are well-positioned to speak to the many positives of working for IBM. Here are some potential pros that you could highlight: Opportunities for Growth: IBM is a massive company with a diverse range of business units and functions. This means that there are numerous opportunities for employees to grow their careers, both vertically and horizontally. You yourself have been able to do so, which is a testament to the company's commitment to developing its talent. Access to Cutting-Edge Technology: As a technology company, IBM is at the forefront of many emerging trends and innovations. This means that employees have the opportunity to work with some of the most advanced technology available, which can be both intellectually stimulating and career-enhancing. Competitive Compensation and Benefits: IBM is known for offering its employees competitive compensation and benefits packages. This can include things like health insurance, retirement plans, and paid time off. Additionally, the company may offer perks like flexible work arrangements, employee discounts, and tuition reimbursement. Company Culture: IBM places a strong emphasis on values such as diversity, inclusion, and sustainability. This can be appealing to employees who want to work for a company that aligns with their personal values. Additionally, the company fosters a collaborative and team-oriented culture, which can be both supportive and motivating. Global Reach: IBM is a truly global company, with operations in more than 170 countries. This means that employees have the opportunity to work with colleagues from around the world, gaining exposure to different cultures and ways of thinking. Additionally, the company's global reach can provide employees with opportunities to work on projects with international scope and impact. Overall, working for IBM can be a highly rewarding experience, with opportunities for growth, access to cutting-edge technology, competitive compensation and benefits, a strong company culture, and global reach. As someone who has been with the company for over a decade, you are a testament to the many positives of working for IBM.
Cons: It's important to recognize that while working for IBM can offer numerous advantages, there may also be some potential drawbacks or challenges. Based on your experience, here are some cons that you could mention: Poor Management: Unfortunately, not all managers are created equal, and some may not be effective at their jobs. As you mentioned, you've worked under 17 managers in your time at IBM, and some of them may have been problematic. This can be especially frustrating if a manager doesn't like you personally, as it can impact your professional growth and advancement. Pressure to Conform: You also mentioned that there can be pressure to be a "yes man" and conform to management's expectations. This can be a challenge for employees who want to think independently or challenge the status quo. If the company culture is overly rigid or hierarchical, it can be difficult to thrive if you don't fit into the mold that's expected of you. Performance Expectations: Like many companies, IBM likely has performance expectations that employees are expected to meet. However, if the bar is set too high or the metrics used to evaluate performance are flawed, it can be demotivating or discouraging for employees who are trying to do their best. Large Company Dynamics: IBM is a massive company with many moving parts, which can make it difficult for employees to navigate or feel like they're making an impact. If you're working on a large team or project, it can be easy to feel like a small cog in a big machine. Changing Industry Landscape: As a technology company, IBM is operating in a rapidly-changing industry that can be difficult to keep up with. If the company is slow to adapt to new trends or technologies, it can be frustrating for employees who want to stay on the cutting edge. Overall, while there are certainly benefits to working for IBM, there may also be some challenges or drawbacks to consider. These can include poor management, pressure to conform, high performance expectations, the dynamics of a large company, and a changing industry landscape.

Pros: Initially great promises but it ended in chaos
Cons: As much as I'd like to reminisce about the good times I had at my job, it is essential to provide an honest and candid review for the benefit of others seeking employment opportunities from IBM. My time at this company was quite tumultuous and eventually ended on a sour note. The company initially showed great promise, and I was genuinely excited about the work and the potential for growth. However, as time went on, it became evident that there were deep-rooted issues with the company's leadership. There was a lack of clear direction, poor communication, and a noticeable disconnection between management and the rest of the employees. One major downfall was the company's decision to undergo a restructuring process. While reorganizations can sometimes lead to positive changes, in this case, it only resulted in chaos and confusion. Key roles were eliminated, leading to a considerable loss of talent and expertise. This had a severe impact on the team's productivity and morale. The handling of the restructuring process was unprofessional and lacked transparency. Thousands of employees, including myself, were laid off without any prior warning or proper support during the transition. This abrupt termination left a lasting negative impact on my professional and personal life. They didn’t even give any of us an exit survey when we left. Moreover, the hazardous issues with leadership were not just limited to their decisions during the restructuring. There were instances of favoritism, unequal treatment, and a failure to address concerns raised by employees. The toxic work environment created an atmosphere of fear and distrust, hindering collaboration and creativity. Overall, I cannot in good conscience recommend this company to anyone seeking employment. The combination of the poorly executed restructuring process and the hazardous leadership made for a detrimental work experience along with horrible pay and benefits compared to industry standards. I hope that the company will learn from its mistakes and improve, but I would advise potential employees to approach with caution.

Job Title: Sr software development engineer in test
Pros: There are several potential benefits to working at IBM, including: Global reputation: IBM is a well-known and respected technology company with a long history of innovation and leadership in the industry. Career opportunities: IBM offers a wide range of career opportunities across various business units, functions, and geographies. The company is also committed to promoting from within and investing in the development of its employees. Competitive compensation and benefits: IBM offers competitive salaries, bonuses, and benefits packages that include healthcare, retirement plans, and other perks. Flexible work arrangements: IBM has a culture of flexibility, with many employees able to work remotely or on flexible schedules. This can be particularly attractive to those seeking a better work-life balance. Focus on diversity and inclusion: IBM has made a strong commitment to diversity and inclusion, with a range of initiatives designed to foster a more inclusive workplace. Innovative projects and technology: IBM is involved in a wide range of innovative projects and cutting-edge technologies, providing employees with opportunities to work on exciting and challenging projects.
Cons: While there are many potential benefits to working at IBM, there are also some potential downsides, including: Large corporate culture: IBM is a large, global organization with a complex structure that can sometimes make it challenging for employees to navigate. High workload and pressure: Working at a technology company like IBM can be demanding, with high workloads and tight deadlines. Limited work-life balance: While IBM does offer flexible work arrangements, some employees may find that they are required to work long hours or be constantly available, which can negatively impact their work-life balance. Slow decision-making: Due to its size and bureaucratic structure, IBM can sometimes be slow to make decisions, which can be frustrating for employees. Constant restructuring and layoffs: IBM has undergone significant restructuring and layoffs in recent years as it adapts to changing market conditions, which can create a sense of instability and uncertainty among employees.

Cons: Long Hours, little work life balance

Pros: Generally viewed as a stable company that exists worldwide. They won't be going out of business anytime soon and they are resistant to letting people go no matter how under performing an employee is.
Cons: Pay will be at the low end of the tech industry. Quality of skills is also low compared to other companies. People are not hired based on having good skills, or ever the right skills, but more often just getting warm bodies to fill spots. This is very evident to anyone who has worked there for a long time. The quality of employees was much higher a decade or more ago. Not even close today. The fact that there are much better companies, and ones that pay much better, has resulted in IBM picking up the lower end workers. It affects team morale and frustration levels as higher performers have to spend most of their time covering for the lower performers.

Pros: If you know someone, then you get a job and are promoted. If not, then you will never get an opportunity to move out of your role.
Cons: IBM is basically rubbing sticks together to make fire, burning wood to make charcoal to write to each other, and absolutely refuses to move into the present time. Most people that work here have been with the company for over 20 years and have worked themselves into positions that are resilient to layoffs, so those that get brought onboard and laid off every 5 years cannot make a dent in the primitive technology they use. Most people’s mentalities are narrow, work in silos, are pretty hostile to feedback and resist change as if it were the plague.

Pros: IBM has always had a reputation for attracting and hiring the best. That is evident in all interactions with your peers. They are smart, helpful, and care about solving the problems, more than getting accolades. IBM provides lots of tools for bettering your career and yourself. It has as much of a "Small Family Company" feel as is possible, with the local management empowerment, despite its size. Another benefit is that IBM really rewards performance, not pedigree. IBM advances it's employees to titles, roles, and responsibilities commensurate with their abilities, and has similarly limited others with better credentials. Most accept and celebrate this, not begrudge it.
Cons: It is a big corporation.. there are global corporate policies (hoops to jump through) from everything from software procurement to annual appraisal, but overall, they are reasonable.
